How to:

Here we will discuss how to use the package and how to get started with it. We will lateron also discuss additional features ant tricks to get the most out of the package.

How to use:

First of all install the package either from PyPi or by using a wheel from the dist folder. You can also clone the repository and use it as is or create your own wheel by running pyhton setup.py bdist_wheel. I would always recommend to use a virtual environment to install the package and use the wheel.

Then try out the example script which should be somewhere in the repository. (#todo) Anyways, here is a short example of how to use the package:

Simple usage example using the SnomMeasurement class:

This is a very simple example using just some base functions without any extra parameters.

 1# Load the main functionality from the package, in this case the SnomMeasurement class.
 2from snom_analysis.main import SnomMeasurement
 3
 4# Create an instance of the SnomMeasurement class by providing the path to the measurement folder.
 5measurement = SnomMeasurement('path/to/your/measurement/folder')
 6
 7# Now you can access the data and the functions of the measurement instance.
 8# For example you can plot the data by calling the plot function.
 9measurement.display_channels() # if you don't specify any arguments all channels will be plotted.
10
11# You can also apply some modifications to the data, for example you can crop the data.
12# If you don't specify any arguments you will be asked to provide the cropping range using
13# some default channel and the crop will be applied to all channels.
14measurement.cut_channels()
15
16# You can also blurr the data using a gaussian filter.
17# If you want to blurr phase data you will need to have
18# the phase and amplitude channels of the same demodulation in memory.
19measurement.gauss_filter_channels_complex()
20
21# Now you can plot the data again to see the modifications.
22measurement.display_channels()
23
24# You can also compare the data before and after the modifications.
25measurement.display_all_subplots()
26
27# If you are happy with the modifications you can save the data.
28# This will save the data to a new .gsf file in the measurement folder.
29measurement.save_to_gsf()
30# Per default the '_manipulated' suffix will be added to the filename,
31# to ensure you don't overwrite the original data.

More advanced usage example using the SnomMeasurement class:

This is an example using the tkinter filedialog and some more advanced fuctions.

 1# Import filedialog to open a file dialog to select the measurement folder.
 2from tkinter import filedialog
 3
 4# Load the main functionality from the package, in this case the SnomMeasurement class.
 5from snom_analysis.main import SnomMeasurement
 6
 7# Open a file dialog to select the measurement folder.
 8directory = filedialog.askdirectory()
 9
10# It is always a good idea to select the channels you want to use before loading the data.
11channels = ['O2P', 'O2A', 'Z C']
12
13# Create an instance of the SnomMeasurement class by providing the path to the measurement folder.
14measurement = SnomMeasurement(directory, channels)
15
16# I always like to set the minimum of the height channel to zero.
17# But be aware that most functions accept a list of channels as argument, even if it is just one.
18measurement.set_min_to_zero(['Z C'])
19
20# You can also add a scalebar, which will be saved to the plot memory.
21measurement.scalebar(['Z C'])
22
23# You can shift the phase-offset of the phase channel.
24# Some functions will take additional parameters, if given they will apply directly.
25# If not they will promt the user with a popup window to select the parameters manually.
26measurement.shift_phase()
27# or you can specify the shift directly.
28measurement.shift_phase(shift=0.3)
29
30# You can also aplly corrections such as a linear 2 point based y-phase drift correction.
31measurement.correct_phase_drift()
32# or a nonlinear dift correction, wich takes into account each line and also applies
33# a linear correction in x-direction if both sides are specified
34measurement.level_data_columnwise()
35
36# Now you can plot the data.
37measurement.display_channels()
